rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;2b0bad97.1503">   <title>Fwd: Journal of World Popular Music 1.2 (2014) out now! </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;2b0bad97.1503</link>   <description> ***apologies for cross-posting***<br><br>We are very pleased to announce the publication of issue 1.2 (2014) of the Journal of World Popular Music. Please click on the below titles to read the e-version of articles (via subscription) and reviews (free access).<br><br>We currently welcome submissions of articles, interviews, photography essays, poetry and art essays, audio and video submissions, alongside reviews of relevant books, special issues, magazines, CDs, websites, DVDs, online music releases, exhibitions, artwork, radio programs and world music festivals. Potential contributors, please follow this link: http://www.equinoxpub.com/journals/index.php/JWPM/about/submissions. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T07:57:22+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Krueger, Simone</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;2b0bad97.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;a3563963.1503">   <title>City University London, Research Seminar 4th March </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;a3563963.1503</link>   <description> City University London<br>Music Department<br>2014-15 Research Seminar Series<br><br>Wednesday 4th March 2015, 5.30-7.30pm<br><br>College Building, Room AG09<br>St John's Street, London EC1V 4BP<br><br>ALL WELCOME<br><br>Professor John Sloboda &amp; Dr. Karen Wise (Guildhall School of Music &amp; Drama)<br><br>'Enhancing audience engagement in live concerts through deepening access to performers and composers.'<br><br>Description:<br><br>For a number of years, a group of staff at the Guildhall School of Music & Drama have been experimenting with the potentialities of deepening the connection between those on stage and those in the audience through the use of "enriching" processes which extend outside the space-time [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T13:17:18+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;a3563963.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;d3888192.1502">   <title>Advance Notice: Middle East and Central Asia Music Forum, Friday 22nd May 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;d3888192.1502</link>   <description> Advance Notice:<br><br>Middle East and Central Asia Music Forum<br><br>The next meeting of the Middle East and Central Asia Music Forum will take place on:<br><br>Friday 22nd May 2015, 9.30 to 6.45pm<br><br>Music Department, City University London, College Building, Room AG09 Maps and directions&lt;http://www.city.ac.uk/visit&gt;<br><br>Followed by an evening concert at 7pm, details to be confirmed. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T09:36:02+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;d3888192.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;3d2f1075.1502">   <title>marceltomasek4@yahoo.com </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;3d2f1075.1502</link>   <description> http://www.southfloridasecurityschool.com/mc/hrhnunhuuceusliwmprw.cgmiunddwuwgdtiowxsbrzkdhfbqhzfbzrgscfw    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-09T01:47:33+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>marceltomasek4</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;3d2f1075.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;76877da0.1502">   <title>Call for book proposals: Equinox Studies in Ethnomusicology </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;76877da0.1502</link>   <description> ***apologies for cross-posting***<br><br>CALL FOR BOOK PROPOSALS FOR NEW BOOK SERIES:<br><br>Equinox Studies in Ethnomusicology<br>Book series editors: Simone Kr\ufffd\ufffdger and Britta Sweers<br><br>Equinox Studies in Ethnomusicology publishes monographs and edited collections on contemporaneous explanations surrounding the nature of music and human beings in a (post-)global world. Books in this series encompass a comprehensively wide selection of subject matters alongside a shared interest in fieldwork-physical, virtual, historical-and its complex challenges and fascinations in a postcolonial age. Topics include music's use in social, collective and psychological life; musical individuals; music in globalization and migration; music education; music, ethnicity and gender; and [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-05T10:59:50+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Krueger, Simone</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;76877da0.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;4a6fdb23.1502">   <title>Reminder: City University London, Research Seminar 11th February </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;4a6fdb23.1502</link>   <description> City University London<br>Music Department<br>2014-15 Research Seminar Series<br><br>Wednesday 11th February 2015, 5.30-7.30pm<br><br>College Building, Room AG09<br>St John's Street, London EC1V 4BP<br><br>ALL WELCOME<br><br>Dr. Justin Williams (University of Bristol)<br>'Toward a Sloanist Theory of Popular Music Production'<br>http://www.city.ac.uk/events/2015/february/toward-a-sloanist-theory-of-popular-music-production &lt;http://www.city.ac.uk/events/2015/february/toward-a-sloanist-theory-of-popular-music-production&gt;<br><br>While a number of scholars have theorised links between music and industrial production developments within Fordist and post-Fordist frameworks, these studies often neglect a related aspect to such capitalist strategies: the upgrading or updating of cultural products (e.g. cars, computers, iPhones). This paper begins to outline the key aspects of what could be deemed as 'Sloanism' in cultural [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-05T09:03:16+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;4a6fdb23.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;83d612cc.1501">   <title>Music, Sound, and the Moving Image - New Issue Alert </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;83d612cc.1501</link>   <description> Dear members,<br><br>Volume 8, Number 2 / Autumn 2014 of Music, Sound, and the Moving Image is now available on the liverpool.metapress.com website at http://liverpool.metapress.com/content/x8135121755u/.<br><br>Music, Sound, and the Moving Image is the first international scholarly journal devoted to the study of the interaction between music and sound within the entirety of moving image media - film, television, music video, advertising, computer games, mixed-media installation, digital art, live cinema, et alia. You can keep up to date with the journal by clicking here<https://liverpool.metapress.com/content/121629/toc-alert> to sign up to new issue alerts, and can learn more about the title at its website [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-26T10:56:40+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Baldry, Chantel</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;83d612cc.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;38b82f83.1501">   <title>City University London, Research Seminar 11th February </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;38b82f83.1501</link>   <description> City University London<br>Music Department<br>2014-15 Research Seminar Series<br><br>Wednesday 11th February 2015, 5.30-7.30pm<br><br>College Building, Room AG09<br>St John's Street, London EC1V 4BP<br><br>ALL WELCOME<br><br>Dr. Justin Williams (University of Bristol)<br>'Toward a Sloanist Theory of Popular Music Production'<br>http://www.city.ac.uk/events/2015/february/toward-a-sloanist-theory-of-popular-music-production &lt;http://www.city.ac.uk/events/2015/february/toward-a-sloanist-theory-of-popular-music-production&gt;<br><br>While a number of scholars have theorised links between music and industrial production developments within Fordist and post-Fordist frameworks, these studies often neglect a related aspect to such capitalist strategies: the upgrading or updating of cultural products (e.g. cars, computers, iPhones). This paper begins to outline the key aspects of what could be deemed as 'Sloanism' in cultural [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-15T08:09:24+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;38b82f83.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;15238beb.1412">   <title>English Fiddle Symposium </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;15238beb.1412</link>   <description> Call for Papers &amp; Participants<br><br>The English Fiddle Symposium<br><br>International Centre for Music Studies, Newcastle University<br><br>In partnership with The Sage Gateshead<br><br>Directors: Eliza Carthy and Catriona Macdonald<br><br>Dates: Thu 30 April and Friday 1 May 2015<br><br>We are pleased to announce the first English Fiddle Symposium, organised by Newcastle University in partnership with Sage Gateshead. The Symposium is designed as a sister event to the Folkworks Fiddles on Fire festival at Sage Gateshead, to run 2 to 3 May 2015. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-12-29T20:46:55+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Simon McKerrell</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;15238beb.1412</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;5e69e63e.1412">   <title>Music and Social Change in South Africa - Maskanda Past and Present </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;5e69e63e.1412</link>   <description> Dear ETHNO-UK subscribers,<br><br>We hope you find this title of interest.<br><br>[Music and Social Change in South Africa]&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/music-and-social-change-in-south-africa&gt;Music and Social Change in South Africa&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/music-and-social-change-in-south-africa&gt;<br><br>Maskanda Past and Present<br>Kathryn Olsen<br>Music and Social Change in South Africa looks at contemporary maskanda-a folk musical genre distinguished by fast guitar picking and blues-style vocal intonation-against the backdrop of South Africa's history. A performance practice that emerged in the early decades of the twentieth century among Zulu migrant workers, maskanda is strongly associated with young Zulu men's experiences of repression and dislocation during imperial and, more particularly, apartheid rule.<br>Working closely with translated [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-12-17T14:21:07+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Rachel Shand</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;5e69e63e.1412</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;7e5c459e.1412">   <title>AHRC-funded PhD studentships in music, Newcastle University </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;7e5c459e.1412</link>   <description> The International Centre for Music Studies, Newcastle University, UK, invites applications from outstanding candidates for AHRC-funded PhD studentships in Music and music-related areas.<br><br>We particularly welcome applications in the following areas:<br><br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd composition and creative practice (notated composition; studio-based work; improvisation; mixed-media; sound art)<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd musicology (philosophical and 'critical' approaches to the study of music; music history including medieval music, early modern music, nineteenth-century and twentieth-century music;<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd ethnomusicology (folk and popular musics; global and world jazz; music and literature; organology; diaspora and identity; cultural memory; ethnomusicologies of the West)<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd popular music studies<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd performance (early music; folk music; [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-12-09T18:33:37+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Simon McKerrell</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;7e5c459e.1412</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;71aecb88.1412">   <title>FW: CFP: Musical biography: National ideology, Narrative technique, and the Nature of myth, London, 9-11 April 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;71aecb88.1412</link>   <description> Submissions from ethnomusicologists very welcome.<br><br>Call for Papers<br><br>Musical biography: National ideology, Narrative technique, and the Nature of myth<br><br>9-11 April 2015, Institute of Musical Research, University of London, UK<br><br>Conference Outline<br><br>While musical biography has recently received scholarly attention through an array of insightful research, the sheer breadth of possibilities for the study of biography (and biographies) in relation to music means that the broad field remains rich in untapped investigative potential. This conference will provide a forum for consolidated critical discussion on both the content of musical biography (national trends and ideologies; myths and mythology) and its form [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-12-01T15:40:54+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator> The Symposium is designed as a sister event to the Folkworks Fiddles on Fire festival at Sage Gateshead, to run 2 to 3 May 2015. The Symposium is designed as a sister event to the Folkworks Fiddles on Fire festival at Sage Gateshead, to run 2 to 3 May 2015. Geoffrey Baker will be talking about his forthcoming book, El Sistema:<br>through its claims to use classical music education to rescue vulnerable children.<br>Having been met [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-23T19:01:25+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;84f1ae9f.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;6c79ecf8.1410">   <title>CALL FOR PAPERS: WEAPONS AND THE ANTHROPOLOGY MUSUEM </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;6c79ecf8.1410</link>   <description> The Horniman Museum and Gardens, like many other anthropology museums, holds vast weaponry collections from across the globe.<br><br>In reviewing these collections as part of the Collections, People, Stories project (2012-2015) and planning for a potential re-display, we have been confronted with many of the complex intellectual and ethical questions regarding their interpretation and display. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-16T15:13:38+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Tom Crowley</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;6c79ecf8.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;3b5b32b5.1410">   <title>A Feminist Ethnomusicology: Writings on Music and Gender </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;3b5b32b5.1410</link>   <description> [9780252080074]&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/a-feminist-ethnomusicology&gt;A Feminist Ethnomusicology&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/a-feminist-ethnomusicology&gt;<br><br>Writings on Music and Gender&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/a-feminist-ethnomusicology&gt;<br>Ellen Koskoff<br>Foreword by Suzanne Cusick<br>&quot;One of the clearest overviews of the history of feminist and gender studies-in general and in the specific domains of musicology, ethnomusicology, and anthropology-that I have read. The bibliography alone is worth the price of admission.&quot;-Margaret Sarkissian, author of D'Albquerque's Children: Performing Tradition in Malaysia's Portuguese Settlement<br>One of the pioneers of gender studies in music, Ellen Koskoff edited the foundational text Women and Music in Cross Cultural Perspective, and her career evolved in tandem with the emergence and development of the field. Geoffrey Baker will be talking about his forthcoming book, El Sistema:<br>through its claims to use classical music education to rescue vulnerable children.<br>Having been met [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-07T09:05:47+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nooshin, Laudan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;eeb97675.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;62562ced.1410">   <title>Call for papers: CMMR 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;62562ced.1410</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>(apologies for cross-posting)<br><br>We are very pleased to announce that the 11th International Symposium on Computer Music Multidisciplinary Research (CMMR) Music, Mind, and Embodiment will take place in Plymouth, UK on 16-19 June 2015.<br><br>Plymouth is a vibrant ocean city with a global history which stretches back hundreds of years. The symposium will include a series of concerts, a satellite workshop on Music Neurotechnology, and an unforgettable boat cruise and banquet trip around the iconic Plymouth Hoe from the Barbican Harbour, site of the Mayflower Steps (portrayed in the logo above), from which the Pilgrim Fathers left England [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-03T16:58:59+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Duncan Williams</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;62562ced.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;32726a5b.1410">   <title>Call for Authors: SAGE Encyclopedia of Ethnomusicology </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;32726a5b.1410</link>   <description> Dear Scholar:<br><br>We are announcing a writing/publishing opportunity in the upcoming<br>reference work to be published in 2016: The SAGE Encyclopedia of<br>Ethnomusicology. The SAGE Encyclopedia of Ethnomusicology will be an A-to-Z<br>perspective, documenting musical styles and genres and will examine musical<br>practices in various cultures and subcultures, locations (cultures bound by<br>geography) and movements (political, economic or other social forces). The<br>SAGE Encyclopedia of Ethnomusicology will be organized in the following<br>categories: [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-02T18:02:38-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sonabai Kanhai</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ETHNO-UK;32726a5b.1410</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
